greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Ordinal transform of A265332.
comment: It appears that each group of 2^k terms starts with 1 and ends with the remaining powers of two from 2^k down to 2^1.
This is ordinal transform of A265332, which is modified A051135 (with a(1) = 1, instead of 2). -  after _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_' original definition for this sequence.

A000079 (powers of 2) indeed gives the positions of ones in this sequence. This follows from the properties (3) and (4) of A004001 given on page 227 of Kubo & Vakil paper (page 3 of PDF), which together also imply the pattern observed above, more clearly represented as:
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..8192
T. Kubo and R. Vakil, On Conway's recursive sequence, Discr. Math. 152 (1996), 225-252.
formula: Let b(1) = 1, b(n) = A051135(n) for n > 1. Then a(n) is the number of b(k) that equal b(n) for 1 <= k <= n: sum( 1, 1<=k<=n and a(k)=a(n) ).
If A265332(n) = 1, then a(n) = A004001(n), otherwise a(n) = a(A080677(n)-1) = a(n - A004001(n)). - _Antti Karttunen_, Jan 09 2016
xref: Row index of A265901, column index of A265903.
Cf. A000225 (from the term 3 onward the positions of 2's).
Cf. A000325 (from its third term 5 onward the positions of 3's, which occur always as the last term before the next descending subsequence of powers of two).
results.author: _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jul 07 2009
